title: Bernstein–Kushnirenko theorem
summary: The Bernstein–Kushnirenko theorem (or Bernstein–Khovanskii–Kushnirenko (BKK) theorem [1]), proven by David Bernstein[2] and Anatoliy Kushnirenko[3] in 1975, is a theorem in algebra. It states that the number of non-zero complex solutions of a system of Laurent polynomial equations f 1 = ⋯ = f n = 0 {\displaystyle f_{1}=\cdots =f_{n}=0} is equal to the mixed volume of the Newton polytopes of the polynomials f 1 , … , f n {\displaystyle f_{1},\ldots ,f_{n}} , assuming that all non-zero coefficients of f n {\displaystyle f_{n}} are generic.
